ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Refined public speaking skills and understanding of speech writing.

I learned a lot about public speaking, especially for speaking on Zoom. We got great feedback about our pacing, verbal fillers, gestures, tone, and the content of our speeches. I also learned how to prepare for public speaking opportunities, which was helpful.
By taking this course I developed many public speaking skills. I learned how to present different speeches and how to effectively share my message with the audience.

I developed my skills as an embodied communicator. I grew more aware of how I can effectively use my voice, body language, and words to persuade and connect with an audience. I also learned how to structure a speech of any length, on any topic, to be engaging and memorable for listeners. These are invaluable skills that I will carry with me for the rest of my time at Yale and beyond.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The class was great. We got really good practice and feedback, and it was very engaging. There was a lot of participation and it was a welcoming and warm environment. There weren't too many weaknesses other than that it was 3:15 minutes long, but that was unavoidable.
The strength of this course is that it is extremely encouraging and inspiring. The course creates a friendly environment where students help each other reach their individual goals.

Strengths: Professor Morrison is a phenomenal instructor. The close-knit, small seminar environment is very conducive to learning a lot in a short period (the goal of a summer session class). Weakness: This class should *not* meet for 3.5 hours straight, twice a week. It was very hard to focus for such a sustained period, and in a class that involves constant engagement and performance, I did not find this format productive. Three 2-hour blocks each week would have been much better.

Prof Morrison is amazing and tried to keep the course as interactive as possible - however, of course, it is probably better to conduct a public speaking course in person (although that could not be helped). 

Another strength was actually the size of the class, the smaller size meant we received particular feedback and were engaged with our classmates.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: TAKE THIS CLASS. It will change your life and professor Morrison is the best
Yes, definitely. It was enjoyable, not too hard, and a great way to improve on an important skill.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. This is an extremely encouraging class. I learned a lot of public speaking skills and gained knowledge on a variety of topics. This Public Speaking class is very inspiring. I would encourage students to take this class.
Yes, absolutely, if you are committed to improving your public speaking and prepared to write and deliver several speeches. You get out what you put in!

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.
